speaker: Mr Slipper (Fisher) (11.40 A.m.)
theText: I always enjoy following my colleague the honourableMC 1354 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 1 March 1995 the model criminal code was first a suggestion of one of the state or territory attorneys-general. We ought to be collectively congratulating ourselves as Australians on being prepared to bring forward and support two bills which I believe are major steps forward in unifying the criminal law in this nation and making it the same, as much as possible, throughout the country. As has been mentioned, we are debating the Criminal Code Bill 1995 and the Crimes Amendment Bill 1995, and these two bills go hand in hand. It is very appropriate that in this place we should have a cognate debate, because the Crimes Amendment Bill 1995 in effect will include some provisions which will take effect until such time as the Criminal Code Bill comes into effect in about five years time. When receiving advice on what was proposed in these two bills, as is usual the coalition consulted widely throughout the Australian community. We spoke to attorneys-general and shadow attorneys-general throughout the nation, to the Law Council, the New South Wales Criminal Lawyers Association, the Australian Federal Police and so on. I must say that there were no widespread major concerns in relation to the bills, although there were some aspects which, following a debate in the Senate, were referred to a Senate committee. That committee has recommended that the bills proceed, and thus we are not opposing what the government is seeking to do in this particular area. The Criminal Code Bill 1995 concerns, as one would expect, the Commonwealth criminal law. The Commonwealth criminal law encompasses offences created by federal legislation and by regulations, and the principles of criminal responsibility applicable to those offences. To understand any of the current difficulties with our federal system it is important to look at the various state and territory approaches that we have. Various states and territories have different approaches to whether the law ought to be codified or whether there ought to be a common law approach. In New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and the ACT the criminal law has been based on the common law approach. In those jurisdictions, while a significant proportion of offences are contained in acts and regulations many are based on non-legislative common law principles. On the other hand, the criminal law in Queensland, Western Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory is based on comprehensive codes, and in those jurisdictions there is no recourse to common law principles. It has been mentioned by my colleague the honourable member for Tangney( Mr Williams) that Sir Samuel Griffith drafted the criminal code in Queensland, and I believe that code has been followed in many other jurisdictions. It is interesting to see that the Commonwealth is following the Queensland lead in this area of codification of criminal law, although it has taken many years for this to occur. In the early years following Federation, most criminal law was contained in the Crimes Act 1914. That has now changed and criminal offences are contained throughout every conceivable area of Commonwealth legislation. No doubt there is a great maze of confusion because, to ascertain what are Commonwealth criminal offences, one has to go to the government printer and look through almost every statute. As the concept of Australia as a nation has grown, the Commonwealth has brought in many additions to the criminal law in areas such as heritage, the environment and so many other areas which were not envisaged as being suitable for criminal law in those early years. We have a situation where a person could be charged with a Commonwealth offence in a particular state or federal court and, when this occurs, principles of criminal responsibility need to be applied in determining a person's guilt or innocence. Believe it or not, at the present time Wednesday, 1 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC l355 principles relating to Commonwealth offences are disparate and unsatisfactory. If the offence is contained in the Crimes Act 1914, common law principles apply. For the remainder and majority of Commonwealth offences, the Judiciary Act 1903 provides that the relevant state or territory laws apply. This has created a substantial degree of confusion because it could mean that, if a person is charged in one part of the country with a certain offence, then the prosecution would proceed on the basis of the laws and principles of that particular state or territory and, if the offence occurs and the matter proceeds in another part of the country, then a different law could apply. There are major problems of equity when this happens because the different principles which apply in different parts of the country could well impact substantially on the outcome. Most reasonable people would say, if a person is charged with an offence in Australia, that it is appropriate that the rules governing the prosecution should be the same regardless of whether the trial occurs in Queensland, New South Wales or any other part of the nation. Criminal law is a very important area of the law. It is interesting thatJeremy Bentham, when speaking of how the English common law was made at the time, said: Just as a man makes law for his dog. When your dog does anything you want to break him of, you wait till he does it, and then you beat him for it. While the common law has come a long way since then and the principles are much more certain, one thing that is important, as was indicated by prior speakers, is that when you do have a codified criminal law you have a very great degree of certainty. That is very important in the Australia of 1995. It is important to know what the law is and it is important that, wherever possible, the law should be the same throughout the country as far as Commonwealth offences are concerned. This matter was reviewed by Sir Harry Gibbs and his committee. The review of commonwealth criminal law recommended that there should be general principles for criminal responsibility for Commonwealth law; That report was brought down in 1990. It is interesting that this was not totally a Commonwealth initiative. State and territory governments were very keen to take up the challenge and; as I said previously, it was a state or a territory attorneygeneral who first suggested a model criminal code. In fact, that gentleman was the Hon. Daryl Manzie, who was then the Northern Territory Attorney-General. He suggested that the issue be placed on the agenda of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. Out of that the Criminal Law Officers Committee was established and that has been renamed the Model Criminal Code Officers Committee. This committee has worked long and hard and the concept of a model criminal code, I believe, will become reality. It is very interesting to see that all states and territories are interested, wherever possible, in working together to ensure that this model Criminal Code becomes a reality. The Criminal Code Bill represents the first part of the implementation of the recommendations of the Gibbs review and, because there are so many things that have to be changed and so many areas right across the law, the implementation will take five years. The government has decided that, in order to achieve consistency while the reform process goes on, there should be an interim position whereby common law principles are applicable to all Commonwealth offences. That requires an amendment to the Commonwealth Crimes Act and that amendment MC 1356 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 1 March 1995 is dealt with in the contemporaneous Commonwealth Crimes Act Amendment Bill 1994 which is being debated in a cognate way with the principal piece of legislation we are talking about. Ultimately, the reform agenda is wider than the attempt to codify Commonwealth criminal law. Of course, the aim is to achieve uniformity across all jurisdictions of criminal law principles by the year 2001. Most importantly, that goal has been endorsed by SCAG, the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. I think that is a major step forward and I understand that a draft model criminal code, first suggested by the Northern Territory Attorney-General, will be available by 1998. The bill actually sets out principles of criminal responsibility which will apply within five years to all Commonwealth offences. The principles are contained in chapter 2 of the code. The five-year delay is necessary because there are a large number of amendments that have to be made across the range of Commonwealth legislation. That is because the offences are drafted on the basis of the principles that may apply. The delay is also a result of the plan to incorporate, with appropriate redrafts, the offences contained in the Crimes Act 1914 into the code. It is planned that those offences will be moved into the criminal code in 1995. The act will be proclaimed and will apply in relation to offences within the code. The code will apply to other Commonwealth offences not later than five years after the date on which the act receives royal assent. The bill is being introduced to put a firm legislative base on the statute book. This will indicate faith with the states and territories and will indicate in a very compelling and certain way that the Commonwealth is committed to the development of a model criminal code. I am. pleased that all parties in the parliament support this very welcome development. At last we are getting the cooperation in this area that has eluded us for quite some time. Chapter1 of the code deals with codification itself. At present, all the chapter provides is that the only offences against the Commonwealth are those created by the code or by any other Commonwealth act. In other words, when the code comes into force there will be no common law Commonwealth criminal law . The principles contained in chapter 2 are a combination of the elements of the common law jurisdictions and the code jurisdictions. As noted in the second reading speech, on the one hand the code contains subjective fault based principles of criminal responsibility which reflect the approach of the common law jurisdictions while, on the other hand, it has provisions such as those relating to intoxication, which are closer to the approach of the code jurisdictions. Chapter2 of the code is divided into parts 2.1 to 2.6 inclusive. Part 2.1 of the code outlines the purpose and application of the chapter, which is to codify the general principles of criminal responsibility. Part 2.2 deals with the elements of an offence. It provides that an offence consists of physical elements and fault elements which provide the traditional analytical bases of offences, known as actus reus and mens rea, respectively. Characteristics of the physical elements and fault elements are described in detail in the remainder of part 2.2. The code follows the common law approach in specifying subjective fault elements. The second reading speech also indicates that this was the preferred approach in the vast majority of submissions received and there is a consistency with the US model penal code, the English draft code, the Canadian draft code and, of course, the Gibbs committee recommendations. Part 2.3 contains circumstances in which there is no criminal responsibility. It deals with criminal responsibility of minors, mental impairment, intoxication, mistake of fact, mistake Wednesday, 1 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1357 of law, claim of right, intervening conduct, duress, emergency, and self-defence. The mental impairment provisions follow what is known as the McNaghten test. That test and the relevant provisions provide that a person is not criminally responsible for an offence if a person was suffering from a mental impairment such that the person did not know the nature and quality of the conduct or did not know that the conduct was wrong or was unable to control the conduct. Particularly noteworthy are the comments in relation to intoxication. Under the provisions, voluntary intoxication cannot be taken into account in determining whether conduct was voluntary or whether fault elements of an offence element of basic intent existed. It is actually quite interesting because there has been a lot of controversy in relation to this particular area. On balance, the government has come up with one position. Not everyone will agree with the government but I do accept that the government has come to this decision honestly. I have some concerns about it and I know that a number of other people do also. Be that as it may, the coalition is not opposing this particular proposal. The government has actually stated that the approach taken in the bill was consistent with that endorsed by SCAG. Part 2.4 deals with extensions of criminal responsibility. It contains provisions dealing with attempt, complicity and common purpose, innocent agency, incitement and conspiracy. The bill also makes amendments to the current conspiracy laws to take into account judicial and other criticisms of abuses of conspiracy laws. The provision imposes limits on the situations where conspiracy applies. A lot of the time it seems that people are charged with conspiracy when the Crown cannot dredge up any other offence. I think that what the government is suggesting here is a positive step. Part 2.5 deals with corporate criminal responsibility. There were some concerns with what the government was suggesting here but there has been a recommendation that this matter proceed as part of the bill. Part 2.6 codifies established principles dealing with proof of criminal responsibility and the respective burdens of proof that must be discharged. The government has decided that certain areas cannot wait for the five years and that is understandable. It has decided that the age of criminal responsibility must be determined and put into effect now. The law of attempt must be clarified and also the law relating to conspiracy. Provisions mirroring those in the bill have been included in the Crimes Amendment Bill 1994, which is intended, as I said earlier, to take effect relatively sooo. When the Criminal Code Bill enters into force, the Crimes Amendment Bill 1994 will be repealed. The government is bringing in the cognate bill, the Crimes Amendment Bill, to cover the loopholes until the principal piece of legislation becomes law. The interim measure could be criticised by some saying that really it is a stopgap measure. I think it is important that, given the matters to be covered by the Crimes Amendment Bill, these matters are brought into law now. The coalition is certainly not opposing what the government is suggesting. The matters included in the Crimes Amendment Bill.1994 include the age of criminal responsibility which, as the honourable member for McEwen( Mr Cleeland) said, will standardise the current situation so that persons under 10 years cannot be liable for offences against Commonwealth law. Concerning the law of attempt, the provisions require that the conduct said to constitute the attempt must be more than merely preparatory to the commission of the offence. The provisions allow a conviction even where committing the MC 1358 MAIN COMMITTEE WednesdaY,1 March 1995 offence attempted is impossible. With respect to the law relating to conspiracy, the provision aims to reduce abuse of conspiracy charges. The provisions only apply where the offence to which they relate has a penalty of more than 12 months imprisonment or a fine of more than $20,000. Proceedings may only be commenced with the consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions. So we have a situation where we have two bills before the Committee today. These bills are the product of a long period of consultation, a long period of cooperation between people at this level of government and those representing the states and the territories. I commend the minister on this particular approach. I commend the government and all those who have participated in the discussions until now. The law has been complicated. There have been problems. We have, quite often, continued to operate as though we are six or seven different countries and not a nation. I do w1l.nt to reject absolutely the suggestion made by the honourable member for McEwen that the states should be abolished. I believe in the federal system. I believe the states perform a very worthwhile function. It ought to be remembered that a federal system is a guarantee of decentralisation of power. When we have a decentralisation of power, it is fairly clear that we will not have a concentration of authority in too few hands. If we abolished the states and we gave all power to the Commonwealth parliament and, indeed, to the Prime Minister, that would be a very retrograde step from the point of view of Australian democracy. I therefore support the federal system of government, as does the coalition, but that does not mean that we will not work and cooperate with all other levels of government and encourage cooperation to ensure that, wherever possible, we are able to standardise laws and procedures throughout Australia. Quite often the different laws and the different procedures we have had in different parts of the country have ensured that inequities and unfairnesses have occurred, and no-one would support that. The legislation before the committee today is important legislation. It is a positive step forward. It indicates the Commonwealth's commitment to this cooperative approach. I commend the minister, I commend the government, but I commend also all of the state and territory governments which have been part of this very important process, which I believe will be of immense benefit to our nation. of short remarks to conclude this debate. BeforeI turn to some more general comments in closing, I take this moment to put on record particular thanks for the work of David Neal, who chaired the Model Criminal Code Officers Committee for some time and then proceeded to work as a consultant in the area. David Neal has just recently had a motor vehicle accident which has caused him quite severe injuries. I am sure that all members of this committee would wish him well in his recovery and hope that the sterling work he has done, which has been so widely commended in the debate, continues. We might also recognise the work being done by those in the department that have been supporting the process. They have been entirely committed to it. We have set a fairly tight timetable in going to the year 200 I-the pressure is really quite on them-and they have risen to the occasion very well. I will make a couple of remarks about what has been said in this debate. Firstly, I thank the honourable member for Berowra( Mr Ruddock), the honourable member for Tangney( Mr Williams) and the honourable member for Fisher( Mr Slipper), from the opposition parties, who have spoken. I thank them for their commendation of these measures and the generosity of their remarks regarding the way in which this process has proceeded.

theText: Minister for Justice) (12.01 a.m.'-in reply-I will make a coupleWednesday, 1 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1359 I thank my colleague the honourable member for Banks( Mr Melham) for the vigorous way in which he debates with me and others within government in relation to issues of principle. His is always a vital voice to be listened to in these areas and I note particularly his warning that, as we move down this process, we should avoid following models which have commended themselves in the United States and in Europe but which appear not to be appropriate for us to follow. I note also his concern that we should not allow ourselves as parliamentarians to be drawn into knee-jerk responses to immediate pressures that come from time to time, but should rather look at this as a constructive and consultative process that needs to bear in mind the whole range of issues, including those coming from those concerned with law enforcement, those concerned with civil liberties and those concerned with the community as a whole. As to my colleague the honourable member for McEwen( Mr Cleeland), I thank him for his generous remarks. I too am pleased that Victoria now is settled into the process of reform. The comments by the Victorian PremierI welcome very much, in his commitment in joining with other premiers towards uniform criminal legislation. I close by saying that the thing that really impresses me about the development of the Criminal Code Bill is the way in which all those involved, whether they be state or territory officials or the parties in this parliament, have worked well towards achieving agreement on principled and workable sets of laws suitable for adoption across Australia. I think it is a fitting credit to this parliament that it be the first to enact general principles of criminal responsibility, as an expression of confidence in the aim of uniformity, and I look forward to other governments doing likewise. This bill was scrutinised in detail by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, which includes the opposition and Democrats spokespersons on the Attorney General's portfolios. I wish to personally thank: Senator Vanstone and Senator Spindler for the spirit in which they approached the bill. I know that they have made an important contribution towards the development of worthwhile, progressive and uniform criminal laws for Australia. I might note that in debate each raised some specific matters on which they have sought further advice, and I will undertake that in due course my department will respond to the specifics that they have raised. I believe, however, that the contributions from those who have spoken in this debate have all shown vision. The same can be said for the support that has come for the criminal code from the highest levels of government. The Prime Minister( Mr Keating) and each Premier and Chief Minister have committed themselves to the ongoing development of the model criminal code. That is very important since the project is long-term and is aiming for completion in every jurisdiction by the year 2001. I thank all the members of the House who have participated. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

theText: by leave-agreed to:MC 1360 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 1 March 1995 Consideration resumed from 9 February. Second Reading Bill (on motion by Mr Kerr) read a second time. That the bill be reported to the House without amendment. Consideration resumed from 6 February. Second Reading Technology) (12.08 p.m.)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The Archives Amendment Bill will make amendments of a minor policy nature to the Archives Act 1983. The Australian Archives plays an important role in ensuring that the history of government in Australia is preserved and is available for access by future generations of Australians. These amendments are intended to clarify the application of the Archives Act to two types of records, namely the records of government business enterprises and other commercialised bodies and the records of the national witness protection program. The proposed amendments will not have any significant financial impact. However, the amendments relating to government business enterprises will result in indirect savings through improved efficiency in the process associated with the commercialisation, incorporation and sale of government bodies. The first category of amendments concerns the application of the Archives Act to government business enterprises. In the last few years, the Commonwealth has been reviewing the structure and operations of government business enterprises. As a result, a number of these bodies have been commercialised, incorporated or privati sed in order to improve the efficiency of their operations. Unfortunately, the method used to incorporate or privatise these bodies in the last few years has resulted in problems for the Australian Archives. The first is that legislation used to privatise or corporatise the government enterprise has, on several occasions, had the effect that the body was no longer subject to the Archives Act. The second problem is that a particular legislative process used to incorporate bodies also had the effect of removing all the preincorporation records of the body from the operation of the Archives Act. As a result of this process, the Australian Archives has lost control of the pre-incorporation records of bodies such as the Commonwealth Bank, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, the International Wool Commission and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. The amendments concerning government business enterprises are intended to prevent the inadvertent removal of records from the operation of the Archives Act as a consequence of a change in structure of certain bodies. To this end, the bill provides for:

theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science andWednesday, 1 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1361 bodies that either are established for a public purpose or subject to Commonwealth control to remain subject to the Archives Act unless specifically excluded from the operation of the act; and the prior records of bodies which are subsequently removed from the application of the Archives Act to also remain subject to the act unless specifically excluded from its application. These amendments will preserve established statutory rights of access to records of national significance or public interest. It should be recognised that the bill will not prevent the transfer of Commonwealth records where the government decides this is necessary. The amendments provide for the government to preclude the application of the Archives Act to commercial government bodies, either by means of the legislation relating to the incorporation or sale of the body or by an amendment to the regulations to the Archives Act. The bill will not apply to bodies that were excluded from the application of the Archives Act prior to the commencement of these amendments. The second category of amendments concerns the application of the Archives Act to the records of the national witness protection program. Earlier this year the government enacted the National Witness Protection Act 1994. This act provides a legislative basis for a program run by the Australian Federal Police which is designed to facilitate the provision of high-level witness protection, including the issuing of alternative identity documents for protected witnesses. This bill makes special provision for access to and custody of records of the national witness protection program. The bill: permits the Australian Federal Police to retain custody of certain sensitive documents relating to the national witness protection program, rather than requiring those records to be transferred to the Australian Archives; ensures that certain highly sensitive documents relating to the national witness protection program are exempted from public disclosure under the Archives Act; and makes specific provision for the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, or a staff member associated with the national witness protection program, to provide documents and/or evidence to a private hearing of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I commend the bill to the House. Dr KEMP (Goldstein) (12.13 p.m.)-The Archives Amendment Bill seeks to ensure that bodies established for a public purpose or under Commonwealth control, such as government business enterprises, remain subject to the Archives Act 1983 after a change in their structure, and that legislation in relation to the national witness protection program is clarified. These proposed amendments are not anticipated to have any significant financial impact. In fact, the government has claimed that the amendments relating to government business enterprises will result in minor savings through improved efficiency in the process associated with the commercialisation, incorporation and sale of government bodies. The Australian Archives is responsible for the management of Commonwealth records, including the transfer of ownership or custody of such records. There is currently no legislation in place which prevents bodies established for public purposes, such as government business enterprises which have been commercialised, incorporated or privatised, from inadvertently MC 1362 MAIN COMMITTEE WednesdaY,l March 1995 or otherwise removing their pre-incorporation records from the Archives. As a result, the Archives has already relinquished control of the pre-incorporation records of such bodies as the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, the International Wool Commission and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. The amendments which the government is proposing will ensure that all records in relation to bodies such as these and government business enterprises will be subject to the Archives Act 1983. This means that the Archives will have control over the pre-incorporation records of bodies which are subsequently removed from the application of the Archives Act as a result of structural changes, unless the legislation associated with the change, or an amendment to the Archives Regulations, specifically exclude the body. The government must, in other words, consciously decide whether or not records should stay in the Archives or be transferred to the new body. The coalition does not oppose these amendments. The bill also deals with the records of the national witness protection program. The proposed amendments will clarify the current legislation concerning the protection of witnesses or participants in the national witness protection program. This will be achieved by identifying the circumstances in which records associated with the program can be exempted from being transferred to Archives and by protecting certain material from being publicly disclosed. The Australian Federal Police will be able to retain sensitive documents relating to the program, and the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police or a staff member associated with the program will be permitted to provide documents and/or evidence to a private hearing of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. These amendments will strengthen the protection afforded by current legislation and, again, the coalition does not oppose them. relating to the records of government business enterprises. The Australian Archives has a statutory responsibility to ensure that Commonwealth records of value for historical research or which document rights and entitlements of individual citizens are preserved for future generations. The present amendments to the Archives Act 1983 address a problem which has become evident in recent years with the corporatisation and privatisation of Commonwealth functions. There have been a number of instances in which valuable Commonwealth records have been transferred or sold with government business enterprises. Although this was not necessarily the intention, it occurred because of the form of the legislation authorising the sales. In consequence, there was no longer a public right of access to the records once they reached the age of 30 years and, hence, the new owners had the right to destroy them if they saw fit. The Archives has naturally been concerned for a number of years to rectify this situation to ensure that valuable records are preserved. In some cases, records of privatised enterprises are of no further interest to the Commonwealth or the public, and it is appropriate for them to be transferred to the new owner. However, as has been mentioned in earlier speeches, there are other cases-for example, the Commonwealth Bank, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, Australian Airlines and the Australian National Line-where the records include important historical material.

speaker: Mr Hollis (Throsby) (12.15 P.m.)
theText: I would like to speak firstly on the amendmentsWednesday, 1 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1363 The only existing remedies for this problem are: to seek to have provisions for retention of the records included in the legislation authorising the incorporation or sale of the enterprise; to bring the records back into the coverage of the act by regulation; and to induce the new owner to deposit the older records with the Australian Archives' corporate archives service. All three remedies are uncertain and time consuming. The amendments provide that, if a Commonwealth enterprise is sold, the records which are created up to the time of sale will continue to be subject to the Archives Act 1983, unless there is specific provision for their removal either in the legislation authorising the sale or in a regulation under the act. The amendments are not intended to keep all such records within the act, but merely to ensure that the issue of their appropriate disposition is consciously addressed as part of the sale process. The second item I wish to discuss is the amendments relating to the national witness protection program. The amendments are intended to strengthen the protection of information which might lead to the identification of protected witnesses. They are consequential to the passage of the Witness Protection Act 1994. The amendment to section 29 permits the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police to determine, without the need to seek concurrence of the Director-General of the Australian Archives, that records may be withheld from transfer to the Archives if their release might endanger the safety of an actual or potential protected witness. All records of the security and intelligence agencies already have a similar protection. The amendment to section 33 confirms that the exemption category covering confidential sources of information in relation to the enforcement or administration of the law extends to a person who has provided confidential information to the National Crime Authority or the Australian Federal Police or who has been included in the national witness protection program. The amendments do not remove the statutory right of members of the public to seek access under the Archives Act 1983 to records relating to protected witnesses once the records reach the age of 30 years, regardless of whether the records are by then in the custody of the Archives or the Australian Federal Police. Nor do they prevent members of the public from applying to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of the decision to exempt such records from public access. I now turn from the specific amendments to say something about the Australian Archives. Although 1994 marked the 50th anniversary of the appointment of the first Commonwealth archivist, throughout most of that period the Archives has been very much an organisation in the background. An archives act was developed during the 1970s but was not passed by this parliament until 1983. In recent years, the Australian Archives has sought to put greater emphasis on its public role-its role in relation to all Australians-and to make more Australians aware of what it has to offer. It is thus assuming its rightful place as not only an integral part of government administration, but one of the significant cultural institutions of our country. The Advisory Council on Australian Archives, of which I am a member, has actively encouraged the Archives to be more outgoing and to make its achievements and collections better known. The role of a national government archives is not always apparent, yet it is one of the essential supporting pillars of any democracy. The Australian Archives contributes to the maintenance and understanding of political, social and cultural values in Australia. It does this MC 1364 MAIN COMMITTEE WednesdaY,1 March 1995 in three very clear ways: it promotes the role of records as evidence in supporting the role of law; it supports the effectiveness and accountability of government administration; and it preserves documentation about the interaction between the people of Australia and their governments. The history of the Australian Archives has been one of significant achievement. The Archives has devised a unique system for the intellectual quality of records. This system has become the de facto standard in Australia and it is copied and emulated widely. It has set new standards in the management of access to government records. These standards balance the public's right to know and the competing demand for protection from unreasonable disclosure of personal affairs. In size and scale, the Australian Archives is the dominant archival institution in Australia. It is established in each state and the Northern Territory, as well as in Canberra, and its collections are truly distributed. It holds over 200,000 shelf metres of records of enduring value, documenting the archives of government and people. Almost every subject imaginable is represented in its collections, which are a little known treasure trove of information on our nation's development. Something of the flavour of what I want to convey about the Archives was captured in an editorial in the Canberra Times earlier this year. It described the Archives as 'one of the great treasure houses of Australian history and culture'. It also noted that for most of its SO-year history the treasure has been sadly underdeveloped, under-resourced and underexploited, even by government and the bureaucracy, let alone by the public. The editorial continued: The Archives holds most of the constitutional documents which are the national birth certificates;just as significantly its records of public administration and policy development tell not only of the development of the nation and how Australia's politicians and public servants handled their public trusts, but also the stories of millions of Australians: our Aborigines, our immigrants, our soldiers, our industries and our agriculture, the development of communities, particularly Canberra, and the way Australia and Australians saw the world and changing times. In recent years, the Archives has had some notable achievements which I believe should be mentioned. One such achievement concerns the type of paper which is used when records are being created. Building good quality paper into records of likely long-term value saves preservation dollars. The adage about prevention being better than cure certainly applies when the size of the Australian Archives' existing preservation challenge is understood-those 200,000 metres of records of enduring value amount to over 1,100 million individual documents. Building recycled paper into files of short-term importance also makes good sense. The Australian Archives has taken on the issue of paper quality and has taken notice of the increasing concern in the community about the environment and the growth of interest in recycled papers. It has used this concern to promote the development of archival quality paper manufactured through processes which use industrial cotton waste rather than virgin pulp. Through a joint venture with Australian Paper, Visyboard andUnistat, the Australian Archives has ensured the manufacture and marketing of a range of paper products and storage containers at low cost. The availability of these Australian made products will allow all cultural institutions to have access to high quality materials to improve the preservation of Australia's cultural heritage. On the other side of the coin, in order to promote the use of recycled papers in appropriate Wednesday, 1 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1365 cases, the Archives has developed and published guidelines for the use of papers. Those guidelines set out for the user situations where it is appropriate to use recycled papers and those where archival quality papers should be used. The Australian Archives has also recognised the challenges presented by the development of electronic records, and it certainly does not underestimate these challenges. They were encapsulated in an article in the January issue of Scientific American written by Jeff Rothenberg, a computer scientist with Rand Corporation. Rothenberg began the article with the following scenario: The year is 2045, any my grandchildren (as yet unborn) are exploring the attic of my house (as yet unbought). They find a letter dated 1995 and a CD-ROM. The letter says the disk contains a document that provides the key to obtaining my fortune (as yet unearthed). My grandchildren are understandably excited, but they have never before seen a CD-except in old movies. Even if they can find a suitable disk drive, how will they run the sofiwarenecessaryto interpret what is on the disk? How can they read my obsolete digital document? Of course, electronic records pose problems not only for individuals but also for governments, and they are with us now, regardless of what 2045 will bring. In this rapidly developing area of communication and technology, there are no hard and fast rules. The Archives has recognised, however, that guidance and advice is necessary even in this situation where the technology is constantly changing and hence the advice may have to be. adjusted. In a culmination of some two years work in this area, the Archives in November last year hosted a major conference bringing together archivists, record managers, librarians, other information professionals and computer industry personnel to review the state of knowledge about preservation of electronic records and to develop some consensus of approach. The conference was widely attended from Australia and overseas. In recognition of the expertise of the specialists from the Archives acknowledged at the conference, it is now represented on the electronic records committee of the International Council on Archives. I mentioned at the outset that the Australian Archives has put increasing emphasis on public programs in recent years. Over the last three years, it has mounted a range of exhibitions drawn from items in its collections which both inform and challenge our knowledge and memory of past evidence. A highlight of this exhibition program has been the exhibition 'Between Two Worlds', which explores the experiences of people of part-Aboriginal descent who were taken away from their families earlier this century. The exhibition opened at Sydney in October 1993 and has been at anumber of venues across the country. since then. The exhibition is currently in Western Australia and is scheduled to open in Dubbo in May. Other significant exhibitions that have been staged in Old Parliament House include' Making Ends Meet', which is about the development of child endowment for Australian families, and an exhibition on 'Trademarks' as part of Australia's cultural identify. To mark the 50th anniversary of the death of John Curtin, the Archives is staging an exhibition on Curtin's life, which will open in this building later this year. The exhibition is being developed in conjunction with the Curtin Foundation and will eventually reside permanently at the Curtin Centre in Perth. The importance of exhibitions is the opportunity they provide to reach a much wider number Of Australians. The greater majority of us will never become researchers in the search rooms MC 1366 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 1 March 1995 of the Australian Archives but, through exhibitions, the Archives is able to reach a much wider audience to enable people to be informed about aspects of Australia's history and development. Another project the Archives has commenced is the production of the first comprehensive guide to the records relating to the. development of the constitution and federation in Australia. The Archives sees this as its major contribution to the centenary of federation. Its intention is that the guide be completed and published well ahead of 2001 so it will be available as a source for others writing about and preparing education kits and exhibitions on federation. This guide will build upon a series of published guides the Archives has already published in recent years, such as those describing records relating to genealogical research, to lighthouses and to Aboriginal Australians. It is appropriate at this stage to look at the future environment for the Archives. The Australian Archives has identified a number of challenges it needs to address over the coming decade. These are: challenges in the changing nature of records and their use in governmentand I have already referred to the issue of electronic records in this context; challenges in increasing users' appreciation of the records in the Archives' custody and access to them; challenges in arresting the deterioration of records in custody. conversations. value of records to government and the community but establish standards for documentation; to direct resources increasingly towards the identification, control, preservation and acceptability of records of enduring value; and to promote wider acceptability and use of the archival resources of Australia. The Archives is pursuing these strategies vigorously. I have already referred to some of the achievements. It is also conscious of the need to work cooperatively with other cultural institutions and seeks to do so wherever possible. In meeting the challenges it has identified, the Archives is changing from a low profile backroom agency, which was principally a warehouse for government records that had ceased to be of administrative use, to a modem archival institution which seeks to employ best practices in its facilities, in its handling of records and in making them available to the public. I referred earlier to the access arrangements the Archives has developed. Under the Archives Act, there is a general presumption that government records will be available for public scrutiny after 30 years as a right. The task of ensuring that records are available to the public at 30 years has always been a challenge to the Archives. Honourable members will be aware that the 30-year-old cabinet records are made available each new year and there is a growing media interest in them. Indeed, a straightforward comparison of the 1994 and 1995 openings of 1963 and 1964 cabinet papers reveals the realisation that there is a records superhighway worth exploring. The press coverage this year, whether measured in terms of editorials, letters to the editor, number of articles or column inches, more than doubled over the last year. Given the need to examine records for material that might need to remain exempt after 30 years, it has not always been possible for other 30-year-old material to be so readily available. Increased efforts by the Archives in this area and the development of new approaches in the light of experience are now enabling the Archives to ensure to a much greater extent that records will be readily available when sought. Obviously, the resource costs of preserving and making records available are significant. In Australia and in other Western democracies this has always been seen as a legitimate expenditure in the public interest.

theText: The Archives' strategies in response to these challenges are: to improve theWednesday, 1 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1367 It is significantthat through better management the Archives has been able to handle rapidly increasing numbers of public inquiries without seeking additional resources externally. One thing the Archives lacks is a significant national building in order to focus its presence. The Advisory Council on Australian Archives has, since its inception, identified the lack of a national building as the outstanding requirement to enable the Archives to take its rightful place amongst the significant cultural institutions of this nation. There have been plans and proposals for a national archives building since this national capital was first developed. To date, none of them have come to fruition. Because of its unique position as a central support to government administration, as well as being a significant cultural institution holding much of the information about Australia's development, I believe that now is the time to decide that the Archives deserves a permanent location within the national capital's central areas. I know that the Archives has indicated that part of the building presently occupied by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade-the administrative building-would provide a suitable national headquarters. It would seem to be too good an opportunity to miss and would avoid the need for a substantial capital outlay on a new building. Only when it is appropriately located does the council believe that the Archives will have the opportunity to perform its role to the greatest effect. I have spoken at some length about the Australian Archives-but I did follow some people speaking about a legal bill-because it is an important institution and it receives too little attention in this place. Let me conclude by saying that the evidence is on the record that the Australian Archives has substantial achievements to its credit. It is focused in its approach and has a clear view and strategy for the next decade. It is aware of the challenges that confront a modern archives and is meeting these challenges. If it achieves its goals, we can confidently expect that the Australian Archives, at the turn of the century, will be a vital national organisation assisting good administration and accountability in government and making a valuable contribution to understanding our past and how our society has evolved. theText: The parliamentary secretary asked, 'What has this got to do with the bill?'Wednesday, 1 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1369 The Archives Amendment Bill is a bill which makes amendments in minor policy. Nonetheless, the amendments are important because they impact on our principal source of national records, Australian Archives, which was established by the Archives Act in 1983. I listened with great interest yesterday to the statement by the Speaker of the House of Representatives in relation to access to other important databases, such as those which are held by the Parliamentary Library, and, most particularly, the Hansard records of parliamentary debates. The Speaker made quite positive and progressive comments about the accessibility of those records to the community. In fact, via the Internet, that incredible expanding communication network that Australians can have access to at a relatively cheap cost, people will soon be able to go into the Hansard records and be able to conduct searches in the records, such as we are able to do in our own personal computers which are on-line with the Parliamentary Library. This is a very significant and important democratic influence because, quite clearly, in any vibrant and healthy democracy, access to information, particularly the records of decisionmakers, of particular public officials, is critical. That is why any movement to make those records more accessible to the community is to be commended. The Australian Archives is responsible for the management of records, including the storage, transfer and custody of those records. The bill arises from issues in relation to ownership of some of these records, particularly from previous government departments that have been privatised, corporatised or in some other changed in a way that may mean that those records become unavailable or less available to the Australian Archives and to the community. The bill arises from the inadvertent loss of ownership over pre-incorporation records of organisations such as the Commonwealth Bank, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, the International Wool Commission and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. But I would like to point out that, while the ramifications of this bill do not impact greatly on the man or woman in the street, there is at the heart of this matter the general principle of access to information of all kinds in this country, particularly that information that is contained within the numerous government archives. I raised the question of Western Australia Inc. because that was, within recent memory, a good example of how records that are critical to the public interest can be lost or spirited away in such a way that the commissioners of the WA Inc. royal commission were deprived of the opportunity to verify the truth of the matter in relation to the issues that they had undertaken to examine or investigate. It made for less efficient royal commission findings: because of the lack of particular documents, the commissioners were unable to reach conclusions on a number of matters. That is one of the reasons why I, and members of the opposition, have a great deal of interest in the workings of the Australian Archives, as do the member for Throsby( Mr Hollis) and Senator Reid of the Australian Capital Territory, both of whom are on the board. I commend their work in ensuring that the Archives do reflect the intent to provide accessible information for Australian citizens. I can tell you, speaking from the perspective of Western Australians who live on the other side of the continent, that access to the Archives in a number of cases has become a matter of some concern. In particular, I refer to a gentleman by the name of Mr Funch of Roleystone, in the hills of the metropolitan area. He is an historian who finds his research all but impossible now that the government has indicated he must fully pay for his research projects. MC 1370 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 1 March 1995 Formerly, he was able to have the assistance of staff at the Australian Archives to assist him with various projects. We find that, as a consequence of those charges, historians like Mr Funch and others who reside in Western Australia or, for that matter, in other more remote states find themselves at a considerable disadvantage, compared with those who may reside within travelling distance of the archive. I might also at the same time refer to another important Australian institution, the War Memorial, which is another source of records invaluable to historians who are endeavouring to write about Australia's past. In many cases these are people who are writing about histories that are perhaps less significant in terms of the national stage, but significant in terms of regional local interests: histories of some importance to local people or to people who reside in a particular area. Jim Davies is another historian Who resides in my electorate who has written a number of popular books about Australia's involvement in World War II. One book, The Lady was not a Spy, detailed in anecdotal form the adventures of Army and other service personnel along the Western Australian coast during the Second WorId War. Although it is not strictly relevant to the Australian Archives, it is following down the same issue. Both Mr Funch and Mr Davies, in their respective interests in obtaining information, have had difficulty in being able to get the information, because both the Archives and the War Memorial have stopped doing research for local authors. That has severely affected Mr Funch's ability to be able to write his local history and, in the case of Mr Davies, to write a follow-up book to The Lady was not a Spy which deals with wartime experiences of people in Western Australia. I have made a number of representations on behalf of both of these particular people. In the Australian Archives-he must now pay a professional researcher up to $40 an hour to attend the War Memorial or the Australian Archives to be able to avail himself of that information. Obviously in the case of a state like Western Australia-and, I am sure, in the case of the home state of the honourable meniberJor Moncrieff( Mrs Sullivan)-that is a severe financial impediment. The travelling costs and the accommodation are so prohibitive that unless historians are writing things that are going to be huge best-sellers, they could not possibly afford to travel to the national capital to undertake their own research. In my view, Mr Deputy Speaker, this is flying in the face of the stated policy of the government to make these types of records more readily available for the Australian community. of Australia the interests of all Australians, not just those that live within reasonable motoring distance of here, ought to be regarded. They ought to be given the opportunity to avail themselves of this information without prohibitive costs. On behalf of these two historians I have written to the various ministers to elicit a more favourable response for them. Unfortunately, the best they could say was that in the case of the War Memorial there is a research fund, and that the Australian Archives can provide access to the actual indexes of information. But these people would have to avail themselves of a researcher to pull out those particular documents and look at them and do whatever necessary research is involved. As I said earlier, that is a severe impediment to the writing of local histories in my home state.

speaker: Mr Williams (Tangney) (12.52 P.m.)
theText: There are two matters I wish to mention inMC 1372 MAIN COMMITTEE WednesdaY,1 March 1995 is nothing to prevent such bodies from inadvertently or deliberately removing their preincorporation records from the Australian Archives. This defect in the law has resulted in the pre-incorporation records of bodies such as the Commonwealth Bank, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, the International Wool Commission and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation being lost to the Australian Archives. The Australian Federal Police is a Commonwealth statutory authority established by the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 and, as such, would come within the purview of the Archives Act. But it is important, in the interests of protecting witnesses who are part of the national witness protection program and of preserving the integrity of that program generally, that certain sources and classes of information in the hands of the AFP not be publicly disclosed. The bill, therefore, exempts from the application of the Archives Act 1983 sensitive records concerning witnesses and participants who are connected with the witness protection program. The exemption is not to apply to such non-sensitive documents as those relating to administrative or budgetary matters, where those documents would not reveal information concerning a witness or a person assessed for inclusion in the program. As I have said, this is clearly important to the integrity of the program. There is no point in establishing an elaborate arid secure scheme for creating, bestowing and protecting a new identity for a witness if the records relating to that scheme are as accessible as those of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. On the other hand, I support the call by the honourable member for Moore for some form of accountability. It is difficult to see how this might be done conveniently but perhaps something in the nature of a prison governor sworn to secrecy who can make regular inspections or audits would be appropriate. The second matter to which I refer is a matter of concern. Proposed section 3A provides that a body that was established for a public purpose is deemed for the purposes of the Archives Act never to have been so established if either a legislative provision or regulations made for the purposes of the proposed section 3A expressly provide that the body is to be taken never to have been so established. I share the concern of the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee in relation to this provision. The effect of section 3A is that regulations as well as primary legislation can deem a body not to have been established for a public purpose. The ultimate effect of that is that such a body will fall outside the scope of the Archives Act. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee has commented that this may be regarded as 'an inappropriate delegation of legislative power'. The committee has sought the minister's advice on whether it might not be more appropriate to achieve this purpose by amending the primary legislation, the Archives Act, instead of the use in this way of the power to make regulations. To date I am not aware that the minister has made a satisfactory or, indeed, any response to the committee's concern. On other occasions I have referred to my concerns about this government's use of regulations to bypass parliament. We must be vigilant to ensure that the parliament's role is not subverted by delegating the proper work of the parliament to the government to do behind closed doors. This is what happens when legislation is taken out of the hands of the parliament and appropriated by a department in the form of statutory regulations. Parliament's role is important, not so that we as parliamentarians may have something to do with our time, but because we, the members of parliament, are the representatives of the Wednesday, 1 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1373 people and, as such, are a crucial part of the democratic process. Our particip Ition should be observable by the public to whom we are accountable. Technology) (12.56 p.m.)-in reply-I thank all honourable members wh(, have made a contribution to the debate on the Archives Amendment Bill, in particular he member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), the member for Throsby( Mr Hollis), the member for Mcore( Mr Filing) and the member for Tangney( Mr Williams). In response to some of the com nents made by the member for Moore, I wish to place on the record that Australian Archives charges for the provision of photocopies of records. It does not charge for access to records b:' those who are able to visit the search rooms of Archives. However, Archives does have standards of service for customers beyond which it does not have the resources to proceed. Hence if a researcher requires extensive research to be done and cannot visit the Archives, that per5 on will have to engage the services of a professional researcher. Accordingly, that presents a problem to Australian Archives to provide a senice of the kind that is sought by the member for Moore. One remedy Archives is examining is to microfilm the most important records so that copies can be made available in all offices (.f Archives and in some cases in public libraries. Nevertheless, the holdings of Archives are s( vast that it can only ever hope to microfilm a small proportion of them. In relation to the matter raised by the member for Tangney with respect to l1e implications of proposed new section 3A, I respond by saying that this matter has been dis -ussed with the Secretary of the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee. The point that the comr tittee has made is clearly appreciated. Nevertheless, the power of regulation was inserted at th suggestion of the Attorney-General's Department. It is thought that this is the appropriate Hay to proceed. In so far as this method of procedure is concerned, the committee has been, or ,vill be, advised that the power of regulation will be used judiciously and will not be used cal lriciously. I am sure that the member for Tangney is assured by that solemn undertaking by Australian Archives, given his extensive and eminent legal background. Mr Deputy Speaker, it is nearly 1 o'clock. I had intended to make some cemarks on the necessity for Australian Archives to develop new policies that deal with ile retention of electronic information, particularly electronic information held by cor Iputers within government service and also within government business enterprises. Unfortun Itely, time does not permit those remarks to be made. Therefore, I commend the bill to the ( ommittee. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. That the bill be reported to the House without amendment. Main Committee adjourned at 1.00 p.m.
